brief_summary: Operation Protective Edge was the deadliest and most destructive of Israel's military operations in Gaza, lasting 51 days from July 7 to August 26, 2014. According to the UN Commission of Inquiry, 2,251 Palestinians were killed including 1,462 civilians (299 women and 551 children). Israel reported 73 killed (67 soldiers and 6 civilians). The operation involved over 6,000 Israeli airstrikes and massive ground operations. The UN Commission documented numerous incidents constituting potential war crimes including attacks on residential buildings killing entire families, the Shuja'iya assault killing over 100 civilians, and 'Black Friday' in Rafah where 130-150 Palestinians died after Israeli forces invoked the Hannibal Directive following a soldier's capture. Israel systematically targeted civilian infrastructure including destroying Gaza's only power plant, 18,000 homes, 73 medical facilities, and 262 schools. The operation displaced 500,000 Palestinians (one-third of Gaza's population). Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International documented Israeli forces' use of disproportionate force, attacks on medical facilities, and targeting of fleeing civilians. The UN Commission also found that Palestinian armed groups committed war crimes through indiscriminate rocket fire and extrajudicial execution of 21 alleged 'collaborators.'
perpetrators: Hamas military wing (Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades)

executiveSummary.title: Executive Summary

alert.text: UN Commission findings: Investigating 15 strikes on residential buildings, the Commission found 'actions amounting to war crimes' in multiple cases. Israel refused cooperation with the inquiry.

paragraphs: Operation Protective Edge began on July 7, 2014, ostensibly in response to escalating rocket fire from Gaza, but in a context of heightened tensions following the abduction and murder of three Israeli teenagers in the West Bank in June. Israel launched massive airstrikes across Gaza, conducting over 6,000 air raids in 51 days. The operation had three phases: an initial week of intensive aerial bombardment, a ground invasion beginning July 17 aimed at destroying cross-border tunnels, and a final phase from August 5 characterized by alternating ceasefires and continued strikes. The stated objectives were to stop rocket attacks and destroy Hamas's military infrastructure and tunnel network.

The human toll was unprecedented. The UN Commission of Inquiry documented 2,251 Palestinian deaths, with 1,462 identified as civilians‚Äî65% of all deaths. Among the dead were 551 children and 299 women. Entire families were wiped out in single strikes: 18 members of the Al-Batsh family killed on July 13, 17 members of the Abu Jame family on July 20, 26 members of the Al-Najjar family on July 20. The Commission investigated 15 cases of attacks on residential buildings and found that in many instances there was no evidence of a legitimate military target, or the attacks were grossly disproportionate. B'Tselem documented 606 attacks on residential buildings killing 1,447 civilians. The percentage of women among civilian deaths (20.2%) was significantly higher than in previous operations.

Several specific incidents stood out for their brutality. On July 19-20, Israeli forces launched a massive assault on Shuja'iya, one of Gaza's most densely populated neighborhoods. Over 100 Palestinians were killed in approximately 24 hours as Israeli artillery fired thousands of shells into residential areas. Witnesses described civilians being shot while attempting to flee with white flags. On August 1, after an Israeli soldier was reportedly captured in Rafah, Israel invoked the Hannibal Directive‚Äîcalling for overwhelming force without regard for civilian life. In three hours, Israeli forces fired over 1,000 artillery shells into Rafah, killing 130-150 Palestinians, overwhelmingly civilians. The UN described this as a 'moral outrage and a criminal act.' The systematic destruction of Gaza's infrastructure was also staggering: Gaza's only power plant destroyed, 18,000 homes razed, 89,000 damaged, 73 medical facilities attacked, 262 schools damaged. The UN Commission concluded there was evidence indicating serious violations of international humanitarian law amounting to war crimes by Israeli forces, including deliberate attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure. The Commission also found Palestinian armed groups committed war crimes through indiscriminate rocket attacks and the extrajudicial execution of 21 alleged collaborators. On the Israeli side, 73 people died: 67 soldiers and 6 civilians killed by rockets and mortars.

casualties.title: Casualties & Destruction
casualties.deaths: 2,251 Palestinians (1,462 civilians, 551 children, 299 women); 73 Israelis (67 soldiers, 6 civilians)

breakdown.label: Child Fatalities
breakdown.detail: UN documented 551 children killed; 299 women killed. 20.2% of civilian deaths were women‚Äîhigher than previous operations

breakdown.label: Entire Families Killed
breakdown.detail: B'Tselem documented 72 incidents where entire families killed in homes. Al-Batsh family: 18 killed; Abu Jame family: 17 killed; Al-Najjar family: 26 killed

breakdown.label: Palestinians Wounded
breakdown.detail: Including 3,436 children. Approximately 1,000 children left with permanent disabilities; 1,500 children orphaned

breakdown.label: Homes Completely Destroyed

breakdown.label: Schools Damaged or Destroyed
breakdown.detail: 3 public schools completely destroyed, 23 severely damaged. Multiple UN schools sheltering displaced attacked

breakdown.label: Medical Facilities Attacked
breakdown.detail: Hospitals, clinics, ambulances destroyed or damaged. Al-Aqsa hospital attack killed 5. Amnesty found 'mounting evidence' of deliberate targeting

breakdown.label: Gaza's Only Power Plant Destroyed
breakdown.detail: Amnesty condemned as 'collective punishment.' HRW: 'unlawful disproportionate attack causing far greater civilian harm than military gain'

breakdown.label: Israelis Killed
breakdown.detail: 67 soldiers, 6 civilians (including 1 child). 4 killed by friendly fire

breakdown.label: Israelis Wounded
breakdown.detail: Including 270 children. Injured by rockets, mortars, shrapnel from 4,881 projectiles fired

breakdown.label: Israeli Airstrikes
breakdown.detail: IDF fired 5,000 tons of munitions, 14,500 tank shells, 35,000 artillery shells over 51 days

breakdown.label: Rockets/Mortars Fired from Gaza

alert.text: Sources: UN Commission of Inquiry; UN OCHA; B'Tselem; Human Rights Watch; Amnesty International; IDF. Israel refused to cooperate with UN inquiry. Casualty classifications vary between sources due to methodological differences.

events.title: Three Israeli teenagers abducted
events.description: Three Israeli teenagers (Eyal Yifrach, Gilad Shaer, Naftali Frenkel) abducted in West Bank. Israel launches massive search operation. Later revealed Israeli authorities knew teenagers were dead within hours but concealed information. Bodies discovered June 30.

events.title: West Bank crackdown; tensions escalate
events.description: Israel conducts massive sweep operation in West Bank arresting hundreds of Palestinians. Five Palestinians killed. Rocket fire from Gaza increases. Palestinian teenager Muhammad Abu Khdeir kidnapped and burned alive by Israeli extremists July 2 in revenge attack.

events.title: Operation Protective Edge begins
events.description: Israel launches Operation Protective Edge with massive airstrikes across Gaza. Stated objective: stop rocket attacks and destroy Hamas military capabilities. Over 50 strikes in opening hours targeting government buildings, police stations, Hamas infrastructure.

events.title: Four boys killed on Gaza beach
events.description: Israeli naval vessel fires at four boys (aged 9-11) from Bakr family playing on Gaza City beach. All four killed. Incident witnessed by multiple international journalists. Human Rights Watch investigation found no evidence of military target‚Äîindicative of war crime.

events.title: Al-Batsh family massacre
events.description: Israeli airstrike on Al-Batsh family home in Gaza City kills 18 family members including 6 children and 3 women (one pregnant). At least 45 injured. UN Commission investigated; found no evidence of legitimate military target. Witnesses reported no warning given.

events.title: Ground invasion begins
events.description: Israeli ground forces invade Gaza from multiple points. Stated goal: locate and destroy cross-border tunnels. Massive deployment of tanks, artillery, infantry. Fighting intensifies dramatically. Civilian casualties surge.

events.title: Shuja'iya massacre
events.description: Israeli forces launch massive assault on Shuja'iya neighborhood in eastern Gaza City. Over 100 Palestinians killed in approximately 24 hours. Thousands of artillery shells fired into densely populated area (92,000 people in 6 km¬≤). Multiple reports of civilians shot while fleeing with white flags. Entire neighborhood largely destroyed.

events.title: Multiple family massacres
events.description: Abu Jame family: 17 killed in airstrike on home in Khan Yunis. Al-Najjar family: 26 killed (mostly women and children) when four homes struck by missiles. Several other families wiped out same day. One of deadliest days of operation.

events.title: UN Human Rights Council establishes Commission
events.description: UN Human Rights Council passes resolution S-21/1 establishing independent Commission of Inquiry to investigate violations of international law. Israel immediately rejects and refuses cooperation.

events.title: Gaza power plant destroyed
events.description: Israeli strikes destroy Gaza's only power plant. Causes shutdown of water treatment plants, sewage systems. Amnesty condemns as 'collective punishment.' HRW: 'unlawful disproportionate attack' causing far greater civilian harm than any military gain.

events.title: 'Black Friday' - Rafah massacre
events.description: After Israeli soldier reportedly captured, Israel invokes Hannibal Directive. In three hours, Israeli forces fire over 1,000 artillery shells into Rafah. Between 130-150 Palestinians killed, overwhelming majority civilians. UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon calls it 'moral outrage and criminal act.' US State Department: 'appalling' and 'disgraceful.'

events.title: UN school shelters attacked
events.description: Multiple attacks on UN schools sheltering displaced Palestinians documented throughout operation. UNRWA schools in Beit Hanoun, Jabalya, Rafah hit despite clear marking and coordination with Israeli military. 44 Palestinians killed in UN facilities; 227 injured according to UN investigation.

events.title: Hamas executes 21 alleged 'collaborators'
events.description: Hamas executes 21 alleged Israeli collaborators by firing squad. 16 taken from Al-Katiba prison where held in custody of Gaza authorities. Executed without proper legal process. UN Commission found executions constitute war crime under Common Article 3 of Geneva Conventions.

events.title: Ceasefire takes effect
events.description: After Egyptian mediation, unconditional ceasefire agreed. Operation ends after 51 days. Both sides claim victory but neither achieves stated objectives. Gaza devastated: 18,000 homes destroyed, 500,000 displaced, infrastructure in ruins.

events.title: UN Commission releases report
events.description: After extensive investigation (Israel refused cooperation), UN Commission releases comprehensive report documenting violations by both sides. Concludes there is evidence indicating serious violations of international humanitarian law amounting to war crimes by Israeli forces. Also finds Palestinian armed groups committed war crimes.

alert.text: UN Commission conclusion: 'There is evidence indicating serious violations of international humanitarian law and international human rights law... amounting to war crimes' by Israeli forces. Palestinian armed groups also committed war crimes.

crimes.title: Systematic Attacks on Residential Buildings
crimes.description: UN Commission investigated 15 cases of strikes on residential buildings killing 216 people including 115 children and 50 women. Found in multiple cases no evidence of military target or attacks were grossly disproportionate. B'Tselem documented 606 attacks on homes killing 1,447 civilians. Entire families wiped out: Al-Batsh (18 killed), Abu Jame (17), Al-Najjar (26).

crimes.title: Shuja'iya Massacre - Indiscriminate Artillery Fire
crimes.description: July 19-20: Israeli forces fired thousands of artillery shells into Shuja'iya, one of Gaza's most densely populated areas (92,000 people in 6 km¬≤‚Äîthree times density of Tel Aviv). Over 100 Palestinians killed in ~24 hours. Use of imprecise artillery in densely populated area constitutes indiscriminate attack‚Äîwar crime.

crimes.title: Rafah 'Black Friday' - Hannibal Directive
crimes.description: August 1: After soldier reportedly captured, Israeli forces fired over 1,000 artillery shells into Rafah in three hours killing 130-150 Palestinians, overwhelmingly civilians. Hannibal Directive explicitly calls for 'overwhelming force without regard to' imperiled soldier or civilians present. UN: 'moral outrage and criminal act.'

crimes.title: Attacks on Medical Facilities and Personnel
crimes.description: 73 medical facilities and ambulances destroyed or damaged. Al-Aqsa hospital attack killed 5. Multiple hospitals struck including facilities for paralyzed and elderly patients. Amnesty: 'mounting evidence' of deliberate targeting. Attacks on medical units are war crimes unless they commit acts harmful to enemy.

crimes.title: Attacks on UN Schools Sheltering Displaced
crimes.description: Multiple UN schools clearly marked and sheltering displaced civilians attacked. UNRWA schools in Beit Hanoun, Jabalya, Rafah struck despite coordination with Israeli military. UN investigation found Israel responsible for 44 Palestinian deaths in UN facilities, 227 injured. Protected facilities under IHL.

crimes.title: Destruction of Civilian Infrastructure - Power Plant
crimes.description: Deliberate destruction of Gaza's only power plant caused shutdown of water treatment, sewage systems, hospitals. Amnesty: 'collective punishment' of entire population. HRW: 'unlawful disproportionate attack' causing 'far greater civilian harm than military gain.' Extensive destruction of property not justified by military necessity.

crimes.title: Gaza City Beach - Killing of Four Boys
crimes.description: July 9: Israeli naval vessel fired at four boys (aged 9-11) from Bakr family playing football on Gaza City beach. All four killed. Witnessed by multiple international journalists. HRW investigation found no evidence of military target nearby‚Äîindicative of war crime.

crimes.title: Palestinian Indiscriminate Rocket Attacks (War Crime)
crimes.description: Palestinian armed groups fired 4,881 rockets and mortars at Israeli civilian population centers. UN Commission concluded these attacks were indiscriminate, intended to spread terror among civilians, and constituted war crimes. 6 Israeli civilians killed.

crimes.title: Extrajudicial Executions by Hamas (War Crime)
crimes.description: Hamas executed 21 alleged Israeli collaborators by firing squad without proper legal process during operation. UN Commission found executions violated Common Article 3 of Geneva Conventions and constituted war crime. 16 taken from Al-Katiba prison while in custody of Gaza authorities.

international_law.title: International Law Framework
international_law.introduction: Operation Protective Edge occurred under framework of Fourth Geneva Convention (1949), Additional Protocols, and customary international humanitarian law. UN Commission of Inquiry conducted extensive investigation.

sections.heading: Fourth Geneva Convention Violations - Israeli Forces
violations: Article 27 (Protected Persons): 'Protected persons...shall be treated humanely...protected against all acts of violence.' Attacks on residential buildings killing entire families, beach killings, and Shuja'iya assault violated this protection.

Article 33 (Collective Punishments): 'Collective penalties...prohibited.' Destruction of power plant causing shutdown of water, sewage, medical services for entire population constitutes collective punishment.

Article 53 (Destruction of Property): 'Any destruction...prohibited, except where rendered absolutely necessary by military operations.' Destruction of 18,000 homes, power plant, medical facilities, schools far exceeded military necessity.

Article 147 (Grave Breaches): 'Wilful killing...torture...wilfully causing great suffering...extensive destruction...not justified by military necessity' are grave breaches. Multiple documented incidents meet this threshold.

sections.heading: Customary International Humanitarian Law Violations
violations: Distinction: Attacks must distinguish between civilians and combatants. Use of artillery in Shuja'iya (92,000 civilians/6 km¬≤), attacks on residential buildings, beach killings violated distinction principle.

Proportionality: Civilian harm must not be excessive relative to military advantage. UN Commission found multiple attacks 'grossly disproportionate.' Rafah assault, power plant destruction clearly disproportionate.

Precautions in Attack: Parties must take feasible precautions to minimize civilian harm. Despite 'roof knocking' and warnings, 551 children killed suggests inadequate precautions. Attacks on marked UN schools violated this.
Indiscriminate Attacks Prohibited: Use of imprecise artillery in densely populated areas (Shuja'iya, Rafah) constitutes indiscriminate attack. Palestinian rocket attacks also indiscriminate.

sections.heading: UN Commission of Inquiry Findings (June 2015)
violations: War Crimes - Israeli Forces: Commission found 'evidence indicating serious violations of international humanitarian law amounting to war crimes.' Specific findings: attacks on residential buildings without military justification, disproportionate attacks, indiscriminate use of artillery in populated areas.

Possible Crimes Against Humanity: Commission noted pattern and scale of attacks on civilians may constitute crimes against humanity, though refrained from definitive conclusion pending full investigation.
War Crimes - Palestinian Armed Groups: Commission found indiscriminate rocket attacks and extrajudicial executions constituted war crimes under Common Article 3 and customary IHL.

Accountability Failure: Commission found Israeli investigations 'inconsistent with international standards' and unlikely to produce genuine accountability. Palestinian authorities conducted no known investigations.

sections.heading: Specific Incident Investigations
violations: 15 Residential Building Attacks: UN investigated 15 attacks on homes killing 216 people (115 children, 50 women). Found in multiple cases: no evidence of military target, or attacks grossly disproportionate.
Shuja'iya: Commission found indiscriminate use of artillery in area with civilian density three times that of Tel Aviv violated laws of war. Over 100 killed in 24 hours.
Rafah Black Friday: 1,000+ shells in 3 hours killing 130-150 (mostly civilians) found to be 'disproportionate in the extreme' and indicative of violations.
Gaza Beach Boys: HRW investigation found killing of four boys on beach with no military target present indicative of war crime.
UN Facilities: Attacks on clearly marked UN schools sheltering displaced found to lack military justification; some attacks may constitute war crimes.

sections.heading: Protected Persons and Objects
violations: Medical Facilities: Fourth Geneva Convention Article 18 mandates protection of hospitals. 73 medical facilities attacked. Amnesty found 'mounting evidence' of deliberate targeting‚Äîgrave breach.
Schools and Cultural Property: 262 schools damaged/destroyed. Hague Convention protects cultural property; attacks must be militarily necessary. Evidence suggests many attacks lacked necessity.
UN Facilities: UN marked facilities have special protected status. Multiple attacks on UNRWA schools despite coordination violated this protection.
Essential Civilian Infrastructure: Additional Protocol I Article 54 prohibits attacks on objects indispensable to survival of civilian population. Power plant destruction violated this.

alert.text: Israel's refusal to cooperate: Israel denied UN Commission access, refused requests for information, and rejected findings. No meaningful domestic investigations of major incidents. ICC investigation ongoing.

witnesses.name: Maher Mahdouqa
witnesses.testimony: In presenting report to UN Human Rights Council June 2015: 'What we found during our investigation suggests that significant violations of international humanitarian law occurred...There is evidence indicating serious violations amounting to war crimes. The attacks on residential buildings killing entire families are particularly concerning.'

witnesses.name: Survivor from Shuja'iya
witnesses.testimony: Testified to UN Commission: 'The shelling was everywhere, continuous, terrifying. We tried to flee but they were shooting at everyone, even people carrying white flags. I saw entire families killed trying to escape. Bodies everywhere. The neighborhood was destroyed‚Äînothing left but rubble and blood.'

witnesses.name: Ban Ki-moon
witnesses.testimony: Regarding Rafah 'Black Friday' August 1: 'The shelling of civilians in Rafah is a moral outrage and a criminal act. The Secretary-General condemns this action in the strongest terms.' Regarding UN schools attacked: 'Nothing is more shameful than attacking sleeping children.'

witnesses.name: Pierre Kr√§henb√ºhl
witnesses.testimony: After attacks on UN schools: 'Today the world stands disgraced...There are no Hamas rockets stored in the basements of our schools; there are only frightened civilians who come there to escape the fighting. This is the third time one of our schools has been hit...The precise location of the school was communicated to the Israeli military 17 times.'

witnesses.name: Amnesty International
witnesses.testimony: In comprehensive report: 'Mounting evidence suggests Israeli forces carried out indiscriminate and disproportionate attacks that killed hundreds of civilians in Gaza, including attacks on medical facilities, in violation of the laws of war...The destruction of the Gaza power plant caused massive and predictable harm to civilians, consistent with collective punishment.'
witnesses.source: Amnesty Report: 'Families Under the Rubble', November 2014

witnesses.name: Human Rights Watch
witnesses.testimony: Regarding killing of four boys on beach: 'Our investigation into the attack found no evidence of a military target in the area at the time...This appears to be indicative of a war crime.' Regarding power plant: 'An unlawful disproportionate attack...far greater civilian harm than any military gain.'

witnesses.name: Breaking the Silence (Israeli soldiers)
witnesses.testimony: Testimony 42: 'When you see these [F-16] strikes on TV, a little poof there, a little poof here‚Äîyou don't understand what's really happening. It's a neighborhood being erased, families wiped out.' Testimony 56: 'The firepower was insane. We fired and fired. Neighborhoods leveled. They told us better a Palestinian kid than one of ours.'

witnesses.name: Dr. Rania Abu Anza
witnesses.testimony: Testimony to human rights investigators: 'I have never seen such injuries‚Äîchildren with limbs blown off, burns from white phosphorus, shrapnel throughout their small bodies. We operated non-stop for weeks with no electricity, no supplies. The hospital itself was hit multiple times. This was not war‚Äîthis was slaughter.'

commanders.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
commanders.responsibility: Authorized Operation Protective Edge. Made key policy decisions including continuation despite international outcry. Defended operation as proportionate and necessary. Rejected UN Commission findings.

commanders.name: Moshe Ya'alon
commanders.responsibility: Oversaw military planning and execution. Defended IDF actions including power plant destruction. Later expressed some regret about civilian toll but maintained operation was justified.

commanders.name: Benny Gantz
commanders.responsibility: Top military commander during operation. Responsible for operational decisions including artillery use in Shuja'iya, Rafah assault. Later boasted about 'sending Gaza back to Stone Age.' Became Defense Minister 2020.

commanders.name: Ismail Haniyeh
commanders.responsibility: Hamas political leader during operation. Authorized continued rocket attacks throughout operation. Rejected ceasefire offers. Currently heads Hamas Political Bureau.

commanders.name: Mohammad Deif
commanders.responsibility: Commander of Hamas military wing. Directed rocket attacks and tunnel operations. Survived multiple Israeli assassination attempts including during this operation. Wife and children killed in airstrike August 19, 2014.

commanders.name: Mary McGowan Davis
commanders.responsibility: Led UN investigation into Operation Protective Edge. Former US federal judge. Commission documented violations by both sides, found evidence of war crimes.

sections.heading: Immediate Impact (2014-2016)
items: Deadliest Gaza conflict: 2,251 Palestinians killed (1,462 civilians, 551 children); 73 Israelis (67 soldiers, 6 civilians)
Unprecedented destruction: 18,000 homes destroyed, 89,000 damaged; 500,000 displaced (1/3 of population)
Infrastructure devastation: power plant, 262 schools, 73 medical facilities, water/sewage systems destroyed
Economic collapse: $6 billion in damages; Gaza GDP contracted by 15%
UN Commission found evidence of war crimes by both Israeli forces and Palestinian armed groups
Israel's refusal to cooperate with UN inquiry set precedent for rejecting international accountability
1,000+ children left with permanent disabilities; massive psychological trauma across Gaza population

sections.heading: Long-term Consequences (2016-Present)
items: Reconstruction severely hampered: Four years later, 75% of destroyed homes still not rebuilt due to blockade
Gaza's humanitarian crisis deepened catastrophically; UN warned Gaza could be 'uninhabitable' by 2020
Complete impunity: Zero Israeli prosecutions for documented violations; no accountability mechanisms enforced
Pattern established: Operation became model for 2021, 2023-2024 escalations with similar tactics
International law erosion: UN findings ignored; precedent set for rejection of international accountability
ICC investigation opened 2015 (Palestine accepted jurisdiction) but years later no charges filed re: Protective Edge
Political entrenchment: Netanyahu's security narrative strengthened; Hamas remained in power despite devastation
Generational trauma: UNICEF reported 400,000+ children requiring psychological support

sources.title: Verified Sources & Documentation
sources.introduction: Primary sources include UN Commission of Inquiry comprehensive investigation, human rights organization reports, medical documentation, survivor testimonies, and Israeli military statements.

list.name: UN Human Rights Council - Report of the Commission of Inquiry on the 2014 Gaza Conflict (A/HRC/29/52)
list.description: Comprehensive investigation by independent Commission led by Mary McGowan Davis. Documented violations by both sides. Found evidence of war crimes by Israeli forces including attacks on residential buildings, disproportionate force, indiscriminate artillery use. Also documented Palestinian war crimes. Released June 22, 2015.

list.name: OHCHR - Detailed Findings of the Commission of Inquiry (A/HRC/CRP.4)
list.description: Detailed 281-page report documenting individual incidents, witness testimonies, legal analysis. Includes investigation of 15 residential building attacks, Shuja'iya assault, Rafah Black Friday, attacks on UN facilities.

list.name: UN OCHA - Key Figures Report on 2014 Gaza Hostilities
list.description: Comprehensive statistics on casualties, destruction, displacement. Documents 2,251 Palestinian deaths, 18,000 homes destroyed, 500,000 displaced. Includes breakdown by age, gender, combatant status.

list.name: B'Tselem - Operation Protective Edge Comprehensive Database
list.description: Detailed database documenting 2,202 Palestinian deaths including 1,391 civilians. Documented 606 attacks on residential buildings. Individual incident reports with names, circumstances, locations.

list.name: Human Rights Watch - Multiple Reports on Gaza 2014
list.description: Series of detailed reports documenting specific violations: beach boys killing investigation, attacks on medical facilities, use of munitions in populated areas. Found evidence of war crimes by both sides.

list.name: Amnesty International - Families Under the Rubble (November 2014)
list.description: Comprehensive report documenting indiscriminate and disproportionate attacks. Special focus on power plant destruction as collective punishment. Investigation of attacks on medical facilities.

list.name: IMEU - 50 Days of Death & Destruction
list.description: Detailed compilation of statistics, timelines, specific incidents. Documents destruction of infrastructure: 262 schools, 73 medical facilities, power plant, water systems.

list.name: MERIP - Operation Protective Edge Analysis
list.description: Scholarly analysis of Shuja'iya assault documenting use of artillery in densely populated area. Comparative analysis of civilian density: Shuja'iya 3x density of Tel Aviv.

list.name: Breaking the Silence - Soldiers' Testimonies from Protective Edge
list.description: Anonymous testimonies from Israeli soldiers who participated. Documented rules of engagement, firepower use, destruction orders, and perspectives on civilian casualties.

list.name: UNRWA - Statements on Attacks on UN Facilities
list.description: Real-time statements documenting attacks on UN schools sheltering displaced. Commissioner-General Pierre Kr√§henb√ºhl's statements condemning attacks. Damage assessments.

alert.text: Methodology: UN Commission conducted extensive field investigation, interviewed hundreds of witnesses, reviewed medical records, satellite imagery, video evidence. Israel refused all cooperation. Casualty classifications vary between sources due to methodological differences in determining combatant status.

cta.title: Demand Accountability
cta.description: Support international justice mechanisms to ensure accountability for violations during Operation Protective Edge.
